This Report was prepared by A. Weber, Social Protection Specialist 
(Team Leader).

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  As agreed with His Majesty’s Government of Nepal (the Government) during the 2002 
Country Program Mission, and as reflected in the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) Country 
Strategy and Program for Nepal for 2003-2005, a social protection study (the Study) has been 
included in ADB’s country program for 2003.1 In 2001, ADB approved its Social Protection 
Strategy. The Study will assist the Government to develop a country social protection strategy. 
ADB is already assisting the Government in areas contributing to social protection, mainly 
through the regional technical assistance (TA) on "Strengthening the Role of International Labor 
Standards in Selected Developing Member Countries of the Asian Development Bank" and a TA 
on "Developing Insurance, Pensions, and Contractual Savings."2  
 
2.  A Fact-Finding Mission visited Nepal from 16 to 22 January 2003 to discuss with the 
Government the objectives, scope, and outline of the Study. The Mission also held discussions 
with bilateral and international development partners. The TA framework is shown in Appendix 
1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Nepal is one of the poorest and least developed countries in the world, with $236 gross 
domestic product (GDP) per capita (2002).3 High population growth is one of the reasons for a 
low per capita GDP. Approximately half of its population of 23.2 million is living below the 
poverty line. Life expectancy is 58.5 years, and Nepal is one of two countries worldwide where 
life expectancy for men is higher than for women. Nepal is predominantly rural, and 80% of the 
population lives on agriculture, which accounts for 40% of GDP. While per capita income grew 
at a rate of about 2.7% during the 1990s, the incidence of poverty has remained high, largely 
because of the disparities in ownership of productive resources – both capital and noncapital – 
and access to them.4 
 
4.  The international community is financing 60% of Nepal’s development budget and 30% 
of total budget expenditures. Remittances from abroad amount to 25% of GDP. Even if human 
development  indicators  for  Nepal  have  increased  over  the  last  decade,  the  levels  of  the 
indicators  are  low,  even  by  South  Asian  standards.  The  United  Nations  Development 
Programme (UNDP) ranks Nepal among the countries with a low Human Development Index 
(0.466, rank number 142). Lack of access to basic health services and education, malnutrition, 
high rates of infant, and maternal mortality are the most evident results of rampant poverty. In 
addition, inequalities in the distribution of education, health, and other related opportunities 
remain pronounced at the regional, urban-rural, gender, and ethnic dimensions. Child labor is 
prevalent, and is significantly higher in districts that have a higher incidence of poverty and 
lower level of educational attainment, particularly of females. According to a recent International 
Labour  Organisation  (ILO)  study,  in  Nepal  there  are  2.6  million  children  (7–15 years old) 
working, 179,000 of them in the worst forms of child labor (like hazardous work and prostitution). 
Trafficking of children and women as well as violence against women are problems that require 
additional attention.

5.  Since 7 years ago, the country has been facing a serious and violent insurgency that has 
adversely affected the economy and development work,  and that has already cost several 
thousand lives. On the economic front, the insurgency has been a major factor leading to the 
recent sharp fall in GDP growth, having had a particularly serious impact on both the tourism 
and industry sectors (GDP per capita fell from $244 in 1999/2000 to $236 in 2001/2002).5 
Although the insurgency was initially concentrated in the mid-west and parts of the central 
region, it is now a much more widespread phenomenon. Recent upsurges of violence have 
hindered delivery of basic services and both public and private sector activities, adversely 
affecting livelihoods, particularly in rural areas. Many families have been displaced, and the 
availability of social protection at a time of increasing insecurity has taken a new urgency. 
Unequal development, poverty, and high underemployment in a stratified society characterized 
by social exclusion and gender discrimination have provided a fertile ground for the present 
insurgency to flourish. As mentioned before, the country's human development status remains 
among the lowest in the world. Despite progress made, human capital formation and human 
resource development remain inadequate, and great disparities between men and women, 
different caste and ethnic groups, and different geographic regions persist, which lead to social 
exclusion.6 The Government and the insurgents announced a cease fire on 29 January 2003, 
paving the way for peace talks and the initiation of a process of healing and reconciliation. New 
mechanisms  that  reflect  the  dimension  of  vulnerability  among  different  categories  of 
populations— men, women, and disadvantaged groups — will need to be analyzed to determine 
group-specific needs. 
 
6.  Social protection is very limited in Nepal. This counts for all the five areas of social 
protection identified by the ADB Social Protection Strategy (labor markets, social insurance, 
social  assistance,  micro-schemes,  and  child  protection).  Concerning  labor  markets,  formal 
sector employment is almost stagnant, and the growing labor force is mainly joining the informal 
sector. While it is difficult to determine the size of the informal sector – due to its nature, being 
unorganized and unregulated – it is estimated that more than 60% of employed workers are in 
the informal sector. Among those, a much higher proportion of women than men are found.  The 
informal sector is characterized by variation in wage rates, conditions of employment, and 
discrimination based on gender and age. 
 
7.  The Labor Act, which applies to all enterprises with more than five employees and those 
in industrial districts, provides for some basic protection like number of monthly payments, 
severance  pay,  and  protection  against  layoffs,  which  requires  the  approval  of  the  Labor 
Department. In spite of the basic character of these protection arrangements, they still lead to 
increased employer preference to employ on a nonformal basis (without contract). This is the 
reason why there is felt to be a need to amend the Labor Act to make it more flexible and in line 
with the introduction  of better basic social insurance arrangements that take into account 
vulnerable populations’ ability to cope with threats to income and livelihood.  
 
8.  At present, the formal social security systems (provident fund and citizen’s investment 
fund) cover mainly civil servants, army, police, and teachers. In total, about 400,000 government 
officials are covered. The Government is the single largest employer in the country. Any private 
enterprise with more than 10 employees can join the provident fund on a voluntary basis. All 
enterprises can join the retirement plan under the citizen’s investment fund. However, there is 
no mandatory social insurance provision for the private sector.

9.  Apart from the formal sector social security provisions, there are various informal, partly 
traditional, community-based insurance arrangements (micro-insurance). A Ministry of Health 
(MOH)  task  force  is  working  on  a  strategy  to  extend  health  insurance  coverage.  Health 
insurance is one of the top agenda items of MOH. ILO is assisting the Government in this issue. 
 
10.  Social welfare arrangements for certain groups, mainly under the Ministry of Women, 
Children and Social Welfare (MWCSW) (elderly, disabled, widows, internally displaced persons 
due to the insurgency, children, and victims of natural calamities), depend very much on the 
availability of funds and are in general low. It is estimated that 41% of children aged 5–14 and 
21%  of  children  aged  5–9  work.  Concerning  child  protection,  various  nongovernment 
organizations (NGOs) (about 30) address street children, working children, and trafficked and 
migrant children. The Government has committed itself to eliminate the worst forms of child 
labor and to eliminate all kinds of child labor by 2010. Most of the social protection programs are 
under  MWCSW,  but  other  ministries  like  the  Ministry  of  Labor,  MOH,  Ministry  of  Local 
Development, and Ministry of Education and Sports are involved in social protection programs. 
MOH is running a network of 69 district hospitals (out of 75 districts) and about 4,000 primary 
health care centers and subhealth posts. For insurgency-prone areas, the Ministry of Home 
Affairs and the Ministry of Defense run rehabilitation programs and rescue operations for 
affected communities including housing and life skills development. 
 
11.  Many projects and activities, mainly financed by international development partners, 
have links to social protection. ILO is playing a particularly active role in this area, having 
published several studies and intervened in the fields of child labor, micro-insurance (health, 
livestock, life), social protection for informal sector workers, occupational safety and health, 
maternal protection for the informal sector, reproductive health, sexual harassment at the 
workplace, and the development of a Social Protection Act. Some other agencies involved in 
social protection activities are the United Nations Children’s Fund in the field of child protection, 
Norwegian Agency for International Development, Danish International Development Agency, 
German Agency for Technical Cooperation, World Bank through the poverty alleviation fund, 
and United Nations Fund for Population Activities (in the field of quality of care and micro-
insurance). 
 
12.  Currently, the various existing schemes and activities in the field of  social protection 
remain scattered. While these activities bring benefits, they rarely contribute towards strategic 
change unless these are linked to policy development. Hence, this would be very important as a 
basis for the development of a social protection strategy for the country. 
 
13.  Basically the question of affordability and sustainability of social protection in a country 
where economic indicators are worsening has to be raised. Economic growth may be one 
source that can support social protection. But often, as seen in Pakistan for example, it benefits 
only part of the population and does not lead to a linear increase of welfare. Therefore, growth 
has to be pro-poor and socially inclusive. Social protection can be one element contributing to 
this if the poor have mechanisms that protect them form shocks and increase their ability to take 
risks to pursue livelihood. Social protection interventions can have positive effects on the 
demand and the willingness of people to take risks, and can contribute to building social 
cohesion and social stability in the country. The right moment to start a discussion is when the 
problems emerge in order to be prepared for and to prepare pro-poor growth. Therefore, it is 
necessary to raise the question, what can be the sources of funding for social protection 
measures? (i) It can be changing budget allocation. For this purpose, there is a need to show 
the Government what can be done with social protection, what are the benefits, and what it 
costs. (ii) Existing programs can be analyzed to optimize the use of scarce funds. (iii) It can be

4 
 
foreign aid. However, this faces the risk of not being sustainable. Therefore a long-term strategy 
is needed showing where funds might be needed. (iv) It can be individual contribution (risk 
pooling). Micro-insurance schemes have shown that they can protect people from economic 
risks like sickness, old age poverty, and natural disasters. But also an extension of existing 
social insurance schemes may be an option. (v) Borrowing money for investment into know-
how,  awareness,  gathering  support,  institutional  development,  and  legislation  is  also  a 
possibility; but maybe there is not much use in paying social protection benefits from loans, 
unless it is for pilot projects or for emergencies. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
14.  The  TA  will  assist  the  Government  in  developing  a  comprehensive  national  social 
protection strategy that will not only help reduce the vulnerability of the most needy and 
disadvantaged sections of society, but will  also ensure adequate coverage for most of the 
population and contribute towards translating the Government’s policy objective of poverty 
reduction into effective programs. It will also form the basis for comprehensive training of 
government staff in the field of social protection. This study will be in line with the ADB social 
protection strategy.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
15.  The TA will provide a comprehensive analysis of the sector and will contribute to the 
elaboration of a social protection strategy  for  the  country,  and  will  thus  be  the  basis  for 
discussion of further ADB projects in this field. The following activities will be carried out: (i) 
conduct a situation analysis and needs assessment; (ii) elaborate an inventory of existing 
programs and projects, including nonformal and traditional arrangements of social protection; 
(iii) identify the involvement of NGOs and bilateral and international development partners; (iv) 
identify gaps; and (v) elaborate recommendations for strategic interventions. A tentative outline 
for the Study is provided in Appendix 2. 
  
16.  The Study will also look into social protection programs that can contribute to the peace 
process. While the peace process includes three critical elements — (i) a political solution, (ii) 
human rights, and (iii) risk management — the social protection study will address only the third 
element, with the intention of identifying implementable solutions.  
 
17.  The Study will develop proposals for a strategy through a participatory process in which 
government agencies, development partners, and especially the communities will be involved. 
Several  workshops  will  be  held  with  government  agencies  involved  in  social  protection, 
development partners, NGOs, and academics. 
 
18.  The  study  will  provide  the  Government  with  a  proposal  for  a  comprehensive  and 
coordinated plan of social protection development including (i) a definition of social protection in 
Nepal; (ii) priority areas of intervention including a ranking of priorities – with a special focus on 
self-sustaining social protection mechanisms; (iii) target groups; (iv) identification of needs for 
institutional development; (v) costs of proposed interventions and financing options; and (vi) 
possible involvement of the Government, development partners, and ADB. The study will be 
closely coordinated with the ministries involved and other development partners. It will build on 
a series of studies and project carried out by ILO, which has indicated a willingness to share its 
experience and to be closely involved in the study.

5 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
19.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $300,000 equivalent, of which $172,000 will be 
foreign exchange costs and $128,000 equivalent will be local currency costs. ADB will finance 
$250,000 equivalent, which includes the entire foreign exchange costs and $78,000 equivalent 
in  local  currency  costs.  The  remaining  $50,000  equivalent  will  be  contributed  by  the 
Government and will include office accommodation, counterpart staff remuneration, surveys, 
and workshops. The TA will be financed by ADB on a grant basis from the Japan Special Fund, 
funded by the Government of Japan. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are shown 
in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
20.  The  Executing  Agency  for  the  TA  will  be  MWCSW,  which  will  be  in  charge  of 
coordination  with  the  other  agencies  involved.  A  steering  committee,  headed  by  the  joint 
secretary  of  MWCSW,  will  be  established.  Members  of  the  steering  committee  will  be 
representatives from the Ministry of Finance, National Planning Commission, MOH, Ministry of 
Home Affairs, Ministry of Defense, Ministry of Local Development, and Ministry of Labor. The 
consulting team and the steering committee will be assisted by a technical working group, the 
main task of which (Appendix 4) is to serve as a critical partner in reviewing the outputs, give 
advice on optimizing the results, and support the project in specific areas. 
 
21.  The TA will be carried out over 5 months, beginning in the third quarter of 2003. The 
expected completion date will be January 2004. There will be a total input of 18 person-months 
of  consultancy:  6  international  and  12  domestic.  The  consulting  team  will  include  as 
international consultants a social protection specialist and team leader (5 person-months) and a 
risk management (conflict resolution) specialist (1 person-month); and as domestic consultants 
an economist specialized in social protection (3 person-months), a legal specialist specialized in 
social and labor law (3 person-months), a community development and gender specialist (3 
person-months),  and  a  poverty  analyst  (3  person-months).  The  proposed  recruitment  of 
international consultants for the first two positions, as well as the overall balance between 
international and domestic consultants, has been fully discussed and agreed upon between the 
Government and the Mission. All consultants will be recruited through a firm using a simplified 
technical proposal, in accordance with ADB’s guidelines for the recruitment of consultants and 
other arrangements satisfactory to ADB  for the engagement of domestic consultants. The 
quality and cost-based selection method will be used. A project director from MWCSW will be 
nominated. The consultants will submit three reports: an inception report no later than 2 weeks 
after fielding the consultants, a draft final report 4 months after inception, and the final report 
within 1 month after receiving comments from the review of the draft by the Government and 
ADB. The outline terms of reference are in Appendix 4.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $250,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Nepal for preparing the Social Protection Study, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

DRAFT OUTLINE OF THE STUDY 
 
  It is proposed that the study will address the following issues: 
 
A.  Situation analysis and needs assessment 
 
1.  Country poverty analysis 
2.  Vulnerability profile 
3.  Summary labor market analysis 
4.   Rehabilitation and reconstruction 
 
B.  Inventory  of  existing  social  protection  arrangements  (benefits,  coverage, 
financing) 
 
1.  Labor act and other legislation related to social protection 
2.  Active labor market policy and employment generation 
3.  Social insurance 
4.  Social safety nets (social assistance) 
5.  Social funds 
6.  Micro-insurance, especially health insurance 
7.  Child protection 
8.  Traditional arrangements for social protection 
 
C.  Involvement  of  nongovernment  organizations  and  bilateral  and  international 
development partners

2.  Studies 
3.  Advisory and policy technical assistance

governance, capacity building)

1.  Definition of social protection in Nepal 
2.  Description of proposed arrangements and activities including those supporting 
the  peace  process;  ranking  of  priorities  with  a  focus  on  proposals  for  self-
sustaining mechanisms of social protection 
3.  Target group and coverage 
4.  Implementation  mechanisms  and  needs  for  institutional  development  and 
strengthening

6.  Possible  involvement  of  government,  development  partners,  and  the  Asian

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE 
 
1.  The  consulting  team  will  comprise  two  international  consultants  and  four  domestic 
consultants, recruited under a firm through the Asian Development Bank's (ADB) simplified 
procedure,  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  and  other 
arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants. Each consultant 
will be required to work with the team and a technical working group (TWG) in developing all 
outputs. (Refer to Part C for the terms of reference of the TWG.) The consultants will take into 
account the relevant ADB handbooks, especially the one on poverty and social analysis, social 
protection strategy, and ADB policy on gender and development. The specific technical tasks 
associated with each consultant are outlined below. 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
1.  Social Protection Specialist and Team Leader (5 person-months) 
 
2.  The  international  social  protection  specialist  should  have  a  solid  background  and 
experience in the field of formal and informal sector social protection instruments including 
health care. He/she should have broad experience in developing countries. The consultant will 
ensure  that  gender  issues  are  adequately  mainstreamed.  As  team  leader  he/she  will  be 
responsible for the following activities:  
 
(i)  preparation of the technical assistance (TA) inception report including a detailed 
work plan for the team;  
(ii)  consolidation of TA outputs before and after each scheduled mission;  
(iii)  regular consultation with the Government’s steering committee, the Executing 
Agency (Ministry of Women, Children and Social Welfare), other development 
partners (especially the International Labour Organisation [ILO]) and ADB on the 
issues and recommendations of the study;  
(iv)  preparation of the draft final report with required revisions for finalization based 
on a tripartite review (Government, ADB, and consulting firm); and  
(v)  coordination of the activities of the other team members. 
 
3.  The issues to be addressed as social protection specialist include, but are not limited to, 
the following: 
 
(i)  Define, in cooperation with the poverty analyst and the community development 
and gender specialist, the priority target groups, their exposure to risks, and 
needs  for  social  protection  arrangements;  and  develop  criteria  to  minimize 
leakages while reaching target groups. 
(ii)  Review  and  assess  in  detail  existing  programs  and  arrangements  of  social 
protection by various government and nongovernment actors including traditional 
arrangements of social protection. 
(iii)  agree on a definition of what constitutes social protection in Nepal. 
(iv)  Produce an assessment report for discussion with the Executing Agency and the 
TWG  including  recommendations  for  improving  and  establishing  new  social 
protection arrangements with view to risk mitigation, 
(v)  Propose necessary capacity building for officials to enable them to address the 
needs of the target group through adequate social protection interventions, 
(vi)  Conduct several participatory workshops and focus group discussions to assess 
needs, formulate priorities, and introduce the process of social protection, with

specialist. 
(vii)  Adapt lessons learned from other projects and studies. Work closely with the ILO 
country team, 
(viii)  Together  with  the  conflict  resolution  specialist,  propose  activities  and 
arrangements for social protection that may contribute to a peace process in 
Nepal and that are supposed to address causes of the insurgency; identify 
possible  ADB  and  other  development  partners'  contributions  to  these

(ix)  Prepare  and  facilitate  a  workshop  with  government  representatives  and 
development partners on proposals and studies aiming at a peace process in the 
conflict  areas,  including,  for  example,  the  Department  for  International 
Development,  United  States  Agency  for  International  Development,  United 
Nations.  
 
  2.  Risk Management (Conflict Resolution) Specialist (1 person-months) 
 
4.  The specialist will work with the social protection specialist and help the Government to 
develop a vision and strategy supporting a peace process through social protection measures. 
The activities will include the following: 
 
(i)  Assess  existing  proposals  and  studies  made  on  this  issue  in  Nepal  by 
development partners and others. 
(ii)  Assist  in  identifying  of  areas  where  social  protection  arrangements  may 
contribute to a peace process, 
(iii)  Prepare prioritization criteria and assist the team leader to identify needs, scope 
and types of projects and activities – including rehabilitation  – that would best 
support a peace process, 
(iv)  Assess possible cooperation with various stakeholders and suggest ways for its 
strengthening, 
(v)  Develop a vision paper and a time-bound strategy for implementation of the 
proposed interventions, undertake risk analysis, and identify possibilities for ADB 
programming.  
 
B.  Domestic Consultants 
 
  1.  Economist Specialized in Social Protection (3 person-months) 
 
5.  The economist should be familiar with COSTAB (support from ADB will be provided if 
necessary). She/he will prepare a comprehensive analysis that supports the economic impacts 
and justification of the strategy proposed by the TA and demonstrates the cost effectiveness of 
proposed interventions. The economist will 
 
(i)  coordinate the collation of data on government expenditures on social protection 
(amount, sources, and funding channels) and assess the implications of future 
financing  arrangements  (including  copayments  or  user  fees  on  access  to 
services by the poorest); he/she will draw on studies performed in this area like 
the social and public expenditure review funded by ILO; and 
(ii)  provide cost estimates for all proposed activities, including capacity building, 
institutional development, management strengthening, policy development, and 
investment needs.

district,  community)  to  assess  needs,  formulate  priorities,  and  introduce  the 
process of social protection, 
(iii)  Prepare a stakeholder analysis and assessment report along with a proposed 
participation strategy for the implementation of social protection measures, 
(iv)  Identify and formulate, together with the relevant ministries and government and 
non-government institutions, a strategy for community level support to the most 
disadvantaged groups, 
(v)  Identify possible pilot projects at local levels, including social protection service 
delivery to disadvantaged groups, and strengthening local bodies and agencies 
through training and capacity building on social protection issues to be tested. 
(vi)  Assist the social protection specialist to review existing programs with respect to 
their coverage, implementation, and impact from a gender perspective based on 
specific examples, 
(vii)  Examine informal social security mechanisms; their effectiveness for enhancing 
livelihood  security  of  the  poor  and  vulnerable  groups;  and  inherent  gender 
biases, if any. 
 
  4.  Poverty Analyst (3 person-months) 
 
8.  The poverty analyst will work closely with the team leader and the Executing Agency to 
identify the target groups, municipalities, and districts most in need of social protection. The 
specialist will then

C.  Technical Working Group  
 
9.  The consulting team will be working closely together with the TWG. The main task of the 
TWG is to serve as a critical partner in reviewing the outputs, give advice on optimizing the 
results, and support the study team in specific areas, namely the following: 
 
(i)  The TWG will examine the options to support a strategic plan for social protection 
in Nepal, discuss the funding mechanisms, help identify the core topics and 
policy issues that should be preferentially supported, and identify and evaluate 
ongoing  and  past  studies  and  projects  and  their  programmatic  impact  for 
replication. 
(ii)  The members of the TWG will be appointed in close consultation between the 
team leader and the Executing Agency. The TWG will meet at least three times 
during the study period of 5 months. Members will include representatives from 
the  Ministry  of  General  Administration,  Ministry  of  Labor  and  Transport, 
employers, Federation of Nepalese Chambers of Commerce and Industry, trade 
unions, academia, nongovernment organizations, ILO, and local bodies.
